texts.shortText: Fairly large, firm-bodied, cylindrical worm. The head is distinctive, as it has a pair of small black eyes and a pair of broadly-rounded semicircular palps, above which are three fairly short, finger-like antennae. The first two segments lack limbs and the remaining segments do not bear gills. Body colour reddish-brown, often with pale spot-like markings.

Global: Previously thought to be endemic to southern Africa, but recently reported from Phillipines and Pakistan. Also apparently accidentally introduced to western Mediterranean (assuming these identifications are correct!).

Local/Regional: Southern Namibia to northern KwaZulu-Natal.
Usually found on rocky shores among seaweeds or Redbait (Pyura stolonifera), but also burrowing in course sand or among coral or limestone debris.
Little is known about reproduction in this species, but sexes are separate. Assumed to spawn eggs and sperm into the water where they develop into planktonic larvae.

One of a number of similar large, round worms with groups of antennae projecting forwards from the head, but can be distinguished by the combination of having three antennae (unlike the five in Marphysa and Eunice spp.) and by the absence of gills on the body segments (these being large and conspicuous in most other related genera).

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 68).

Day, JH (1967). A Monograph on the Polychaeta of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London, Part1 Errantia (p. 402).

Díaz, A & López, E (2020). Four New Records of Eunicidae (Annelida: Polychaeta) from the Western Philippines Islands. Thalassas: An International Journal of Marine Sciences, 36(2), 321-332.

Simon, C, Kara, J, du Toit, A, van Rensburg, H, Naidoo, C & Matthee, CA (2021). Reeling them in: taxonomy of marine annelids used as bait by anglers in the Western Cape Province, South Africa. PeerJ, 9, e11847.
